subsection_content_2: . Low-pathogenic H5N2 was detected on a poultry farm in Mecklenburg-West Pommerania during a routine visit from officials. On November 12, the Ministry of Agriculture ordered the culling of 17,000 ducks and geese for fear that the disease might mutate into high pathogenic bird flu. Bird flu was last reported in Germany in 2006.
subsection_content_1: A bird flu surveillance program in Azerbaijan began on November 1. Samples from 18 wild birds and 1,127 poultry representing different farms and private economies were tested. The study had participants from the State Veterinary Service, Ministries of Health, Ecology and Natural Resources, and the Hunters' Association. The Republican Veterinary Lab tested the samples and found no bird flu. Another monitoring effort will begin on December 13.
subsection_content_3: . A 59-year-old woman in Hong Kong diagnosed with H5N1 bird flu has been quarantined while officials inspect the poultry markets. According to a November 18 statement by Secretary for Food and Health, York Chow, there was no evidence of human-to-human transmission. The patient had recently visited China with her family and ate chicken in a poultry market there, but it is uncertain whether this was the cause of her infection or whether she caught the disease upon her return to Hong Kong on November 1.  She began to show symptoms the next day, and was hospitalized on November 14 with a persistent fever.
